title: Grandmother, 72, goes into battle to get a driveway
text:
Ann wants to be able to park at home (Picture: BPM Media)

A grandmother has taken drastic measures to try and get the council to allow her to have a driveway.

Ann Sutton, 72, says she will be forced to park many roads away from her home she isn’t granted planing permission.

She has hung up a bed sheet-sized sign painted with bright green and blue letters saying: ‘All I want is a driveway’.

Ann and her late husband, from Black Notley, applied for a driveway in 2014, which was denied after the local parish council said the driveway would make the area look unattractive.

After her husband passed away two years ago, she’s now in danger of losing her disabled parking space in the nearby Dewlands Road.

She now can’t afford the money to apply for a driveway again, in case she is denied once more.

Ann Sutton lives in Black Notley (Picture: BPM Media)

Five years ago, Ann along with her late husband, started looking into building a drive in front of her house.

Advertisement

Advertisement

At the time, they were having to park their car along a side road, which would often be too full to park down.

‘We put in planning permission and paid and everything,’ said Ann.

‘They came out, and put their sign up, and nobody complained except the Parish Council.

‘They said: ‘Oh no, we don’t like to see tarmac across grass it will spoil the look of the village.’

She got in touch again with the council, asking them to reconsider due to her new circumstances.

But the council refused to, unless she paid another fee to resubmit, something that costs over £200.

‘I tried again, writing letters backwards and forwards,” she said.

‘They came back with: “Mrs Sutton can reapply but she won’t get it, and she can go to appeal.”

‘Being a widow and pensioner, I cannot afford to lose money for them to dismiss it.

‘It’s £206 to put in a plan now, it used to be £172 but obviously it’s gone up.’

The council have also said that there wouldn’t be enough room for a drive on the verge, despite cars frequently parking on the grass anyway.

She decided to take matters into her own hands.

‘When they refused again I just said that I’ll put it on a bedsheet.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘Nobody would believe I would do it, but my Grandson helped me and we did it, and I think everybody was shocked.

In a tongue-in-cheek move, Ann fought back at concerns that a driveway would make the area look untidy, but hanging up a full sized bed-sheet sign.

‘I’m going to leave it up so that it looks untidy if that’s what they’re telling me I would do with a bit of tarmac.’

A Braintree District Council spokesperson, said: ‘This planning application was refused in 2014 because of the impact it would have on the character of

the street and the lack of space within the site, compromising the safety of pedestrians and other drivers.

‘The applicant did not appeal against the Council’s decision.

‘We have responded to correspondence explaining the reasons for refusal are still relevant and therefore would still be refused permission if she did

reapply.’

Despite this, Ann’s sign is still up.

‘People come up to me and say: ‘That’s outside yours isn’t it Ann?’ and I say, ‘Yes that’s me.’

‘Blow it, I’m leaving it up, let them moan.’
